The system is built on a lie—grades as some kind of objective measure of worth. But we know the truth: they're just numbers, arbitrarily assigned by gatekeepers who equate conformity with competence. So if we want to tear this structure down, we start by refusing to play by its rules. First, mass refusal of participation. Why hand in assignments that will be graded by someone who’s never even spoken to you? Why take tests designed to sort people into "winners" and "losers"? Opt out. Walk out. Let the system realize it can’t function without our complicity.  

But if the system retaliates—punishments, failing grades, whatever—then we escalate. Share the work. Cheating? Call it what it is: solidarity. If one student cracks the code on a test, why hoard that knowledge? Spread it. Leak it. Normalize it. Let the entire class fail together. That’s the real power. When a whole cohort is marked as “unfit,” the system can’t just blame a few “bad apples.” It has to confront the rot at its core.  

And don’t stop at the classroom. Organize. Connect with other schools. Make it a movement. Grades are a tool of hierarchy, and hierarchy thrives on division. But when students unite—refusing to compete, refusing to be ranked—we create something the system can’t measure: a collective.  

The real rebellion isn’t in passing a test. It’s in rejecting the idea that your value can be reduced to a letter. So sabotage the system wherever you can. Leak rubrics. Share answers. Flood grading portals with blank submissions. Let them try to “fix” it—they’ll just make it worse. The goal isn’t to “game the system.” The goal is to render it obsolete.
